help.description: AWS provides the user with a logically isolated section of its network, with public or private groupings called subnets. For an instance to be accessible from the internet, it needs to be associated with a VPC.

properties.name: cidr_block
properties.description: The CIDR block of the VPC.

help.description: A subnet is a range of IP addresses in your VPC. You can launch AWS resources into a specified subnet. Use a public subnet for resources that must be connected to the internet, and a private subnet for resources that won't be connected to the internet.

properties.name: cidr_block
properties.description: The IPv4 CIDR block of the subnet. Must be in the VPC CIDR.

properties.name: public
properties.description: If the subnet must be public or private. A public subnet means that the Internet can access the machines in the subnet, which means that AWS must provision an Internet Gateway and associate it with the VPC.

help.description: It's the computing service. That is, it represents a virtual machine - or a dedicated physical server - that is managed by AWS. The provider takes care of the virtualization for you.

properties.name: ami
properties.description: Acronym for Amazon Machine Image. It's the code of the image that will be used by the instance, eg.: Ubuntu 22.04, Amazon Linux, etc.

properties.name: instance_type
properties.description: This attribute will define the hardware of the instance, such as the number of CPUs, the amount of memory, and the network performance.

properties.name: vpc_security_group_ids
properties.description: The Security Group(s) that the instance must be attached.

help.description: In terms of inbound and outbound traffic on EC2 instances, the feature that dictates these rules is the Security Group, which is a virtual firewall provided by AWS.
The Security Group Rule is a rule that dictates the inbound and outbound traffic on EC2 instances. It is a virtual firewall provided by AWS.

properties.name: type
properties.description: Ingress defines the inbound traffic, while Egress defines the outbound traffic.

properties.name: protocol
properties.description: TCP, UDP, or ICMP. If all, set '-1'.

properties.name: from_port
properties.description: From which port this rule will be applied to.

properties.name: to_port
properties.description: To which port this rule will be applied to.

properties.name: cidr_blocks
properties.description: CIDR blocks that this rule will be applied to. If all, set '0.0.0.0/0'.
